fields.value: Playing Out Transformative Adaptation in CCAFS Benchmark Sites in East Africa: "When, Where, How and With Whom?"

dsDescriptionValue.value:
As part of this CCAFS project we collected various types of data in order to better understand vulnerabilities of smallholder farmers in East Africa to climate change.  We collected and integrated interdisciplinary datasets in order to assess the biophysical, agronomic, social and economic realities at the sites. The study was carried out in four CCAFS Benchmark sites in East Africa, representing various agro-ecological systems: Hoima, Uganda; Nyando, Kenya; Lushoto, Tanzania; and Borana, Ethiopia. The information is being used for researchers, policy-makers and development practitioners to better understand the vulnerabilities of smallholder farmers, both men and women, to climate ch
ange and what actions can be taken to reduce that vulnerability.

keywordValue.value: Socio-Economic; Soil; Land Health; Adaptation; Climate Smart Agriculture

value: CCAFS Benchmark Sites (10 X 10 KM BlocksÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂExcept Ethiopia which is a 30 X 30 KM Block)

files.description: This file contains the dataset for 123 households surveys in Borana and can be combined with the CCAFS baseline survey using the household and village identifiers. Although the baseline covered 140 households in each site there are fewer in this follow-up survey because of attrition.

files.description: The Land Degradation Surveillance Framework (LDSF) is a spatially stratified, randomized sampling design, developed to provide a biophysical baseline at landscape level and a monitoring and evaluation framework for assessing processes of land degradation and effectiveness of rehabilitation measures, over time. The LDSF was developed by ICRAF in 2005 and has been implemented at sites globally by CGIAR centres, NGOs and national partners. The field guide describes the sampling design, equipment needed and includes the field data forms.
files.label: Field_Guide_LDSF.pdf

dataFile.description: The Land Degradation Surveillance Framework (LDSF) is a spatially stratified, randomized sampling design, developed to provide a biophysical baseline at landscape level and a monitoring and evaluation framework for assessing processes of land degradation and effectiveness of rehabilitation measures, over time. The LDSF was developed by ICRAF in 2005 and has been implemented at sites globally by CGIAR centres, NGOs and national partners. The field guide describes the sampling design, equipment needed and includes the field data forms.
